turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 642, Edward Boykin, petitioner, versus Alabama.
Mr. Gibbons.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
I represent Edward Boykin Jr. who is the only man in America that awaits execution for the crime of common law robbery.
And if he is permitted to die will be the sixth man to be executed by the State of Alabama in almost 40 years for that crime.
This case is before this Court on certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama.
That court by a four to three decision affirmed five death sentences.
Edward Boykin was brought to trial on five separate indictments for robbery.
And a plea of guilty was entered and on that plea he was sentenced to death five times.
Now, this case as I see it raises three great constitutional issues.

The first one is that it violates the Constitution, the Due Process Clause for a conviction to be based upon a plea of guilty where in the record of trial there is no affirmative showing that that plea was voluntarily and understandingly given.
Secondly, the imposition of the death penalty for the common law robbery violates the provision of the cruel and unusual Eighth Amendment clause.
And thirdly, a statute which allows a jury unfettered discretion in a capital case violates the petitioner's right to due process.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Gibbons --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- may I ask you whether that last point was raised and decided below?
I've looked for it and I haven't been able to find it.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, it was --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: If it is --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: -- raised below.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Would you show me where?
Would you tell me where it is because I have looked for it and haven't found it?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well, it was raised in my brief, I do not know whether the Supreme Court of Alabama considered it or not.
Their decision indicates that they did not.
But --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: There's nothing in there, the decision on it.
There's nothing in the papers --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: No.
No, sir.
That there is --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- we have before us.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: There is no treatment in the Supreme Court of Alabama decision as to that point.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I want to be very clear on this Mr. Gibbons because it's a --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- jurisdictional matter.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: There is nothing in the papers before us that shows that the point with respect to them -- your argument with respect to the need for standards to guide the jury in imposing a punishment.
There's nothing in the papers before us that shows that that was raised and decided below, am I right or wrong about that?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: I would -- the only thing I can say is that it was raised in the court below.
It --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, if your brief here printed in the Supreme Court of Alabama --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: I don't know.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I'm not sure you say it's correct.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: I don't know about whether it is or not.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But it was raised in the second cases to follow you.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well, what I was just about to say was that in view of the oral argument on that specific point that's going to be presented in Maxwell against Bishop that in the time limitation that I have, I'm going to address myself to the first two issues that I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh, is the first issue breaking the law?
You don't see that here, do you?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well, it was raised below in this sense that under the automatic appeal statute in Alabama the Supreme Court of Alabama must look at the entire record.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh, its --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: And certainly it was raised --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- they must have know any clearer.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's that the statute?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So you would say that any clear -- any thing that we might reverse, they should've noticed?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well, they certainly noted that because three justices in Alabama wanted to reverse on that first issue which I'm raising -- in which I intend to argue about now.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well again, did you argue that in your brief before the Supreme Court of Alabama?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: No, sir.
I did not submit that issue in my brief below.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That was raised by the dissenting --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: That was raised by the dissenting opinion.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Sua sponte?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Was there a motion to withdraw the plea here?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: In this case?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: No, sir.
Now, if I may --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Represented by a counsel?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: He had a court appointed attorney.
I might explain to the Court here that I'm in the same position you all are because I entered this case at the trial -- at the appellate level.
I was -- I was not even in the case until after the sentence was given and everything.

Now, addressing myself, if I may to this point that the Due Process Clause requires that a trial record show affirmatively that the plea of guilty was voluntarily and understandingly made, I think there are three points of reasoning that inevitably draw us to that conclusion.
The first is and I don't think it's arguable that a plea of guilty must be voluntarily and understandingly made.
That's because as we -- I think we all realize that a plea of guilty is an admission of guilt.
It's a con -- judicial confession in effect.
And certainly the waiver of such a fundamental right to contest guilt to give the prosecution the whole vote so to speak.
The waiver of that right is so fundamental that I don't think it's arguable.
That it should be voluntarily and understandingly given.
Now secondly, that in order to be meaningful, it must be affirmative.

And this affirmative procedural step must appear on the record because -- what I'm saying here is this, that if you look at this record right here, you do not know and I do not know whether Edward Boykin entered his plea of guilty voluntarily and understandingly.
And yet he is going to have to die because of the barrenness of this record.
And it's a simple thing.
It -- by analogy it's the same reasoning that this Court used in the Miranda decision.
There, there was a question of a waiver.

There was a -- and this Court said that if a -- in a trial court, if you're going to introduce an out of court confession then you -- then the record must affirmatively show that that confession was obtained voluntarily and understandingly.
The -- the same thing is true that we are asking here.
If you're going to rely on a plea of guilty then the record ought to show and -- we wouldn't have this trouble right here.
This question wouldn't be before the court.
It wouldn't give the trouble to the Supreme Court that it gave them if a -- as -- the same sort of litany that -- that's in the record about indigency.
If you had just a trial court determining be ensured that the fellow knew that when he plead guilty, he was subjecting himself to the maximum punishment.
Now, I'd like to comment about this --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: -- record.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What effect do you think the Alabama procedure has that the -- notwithstanding the plea, there must be a prima facie case made I doubt.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well, I don't think that has too much to do with the -- the issue that I'm trying to speak about here for the reason that that common after the a plea.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I know but his plea doesn't become effective, the basis for reasoning, the carrying out of the sentence out that additional requirement being fulfilled, namely it ought to be a prima facie case?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Isn't that the Alabama law?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: No, sir.
That's not the Alabama law.
The -- the Alabama law is that you put on a prima facie case as a sort of penalty trial where you determine the -- you let the jury see what kind of a case it was.
But a plea of guilty in Alabama is conviction of the offense.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean the jury can't -- cannot find the man innocent?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, its -- that's --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Isn't that your answer?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes , sir.
Now, looking at this record, its 35 pages for which a man's going to die for and all that's in it is an -- the first page is an indictment talking about robbery not the death penalty.
It sets bail at $2,500.00.
There is a proceeding of determining indigency while the fellow is asked, do you need an attorney and he says no.

There is in this record the testimony of the witnesses, the complaining witnesses and then the first time that the death penalty is mentioned is in the almost pro forma instructions of the judge when he gives the jury two forms.
If you're going to give him imprisonment, you use this form.
If you're going to use death, you use this form.
And then at that time the jury goes out and comes back in and Edward Boykin is to die and that's all that this record shows and that's what I'm trying to say today.
Now, I just believe that the Constitution Due Process Clause requires that that this affirmative showing be made.
I'd like now to turn --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Did you -- did I understand that there was no motion at anytime to withdraw the plea of guilty?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: There was no motion at any time.
No, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I'm interested in the statement of facts on page 7 of your brief.
It indicates that after this conviction and death sentence there was an automatic appeal under Alabama law --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.
There is.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But that the Alabama Court despite the conceded indigency of the petitioner did not appoint counsel on appeal and thereafter when member of this similarly union attempted to represent him, he was told that he could not because he wasn't authorized to practice?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And thereafter when I guess you entered the case.
It was too late as you say to raise any issue on motion for a new trial as the statutory time period had elapsed.
I'm interested in knowing just what that means.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well, the day of the sentence starts the running of the time when you can file a motion for a new trial and that's --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Apparently the trial court neglect it, it actually imposed a sentence, didn't he?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: They're to set the date?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: He -- he didn't set the date until the next day when the defendant was finally brought back in for proper sentencing as to form.
But the 30-day limitation run -- started running on the day of sentence which is 21st of September.
Well now, I didn't get in this case until the 27th of October when a friend of mine told me that he want -- he couldn't prosecute the appeal and would I take it and that time I got into it.
But any sort of motion for a new trial, the grounds, excessiveness of that sort of thing, that's all waived unless you raise it on a motion for a new trial.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that must be made within 30 days of the sentence?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: You see, the automatic appeal statute in Alabama came prior or was enacted prior to Gideon against Wainwright about this counsel but you have an automatic appeal but you'd -- you don't get an automatic attorney.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Uhmm-mm.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: On that appeal, you've got to ask for it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And by the time he had a lawyer, the 30-day period had elapsed.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And can you tell us in a word what might have been done if the 30-day period had not elapsed?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well, a motion for a new trial and some of the grounds I'm raising now --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: About what, which one?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: But principally the excessiveness of the penalty in the light of the offense.
Nobody, nobody expected -- I can only conjecture about this record just as anybody can.
But Alabama gives the penalty for robbery about once every eight years.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And still, if we can just for a moment confine ourselves, if you're willing to, to the question I asked, what could've been done within than 30-day period?
That could not have been done after the --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: A motion for a new trial could have been filed and heard by the trial court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because he did have trial counsel, did he?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: He had court appointed counsel for the trial.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, yes, it was appointed by the court, that he had trial counsel.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: His duties under Alabama practice are over when the Senate comes in.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It doesn't embrace any duties to make a motion for a new trial, does it?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well, it's the view that attorney's take.
I personally take the view that it goes all the way through parole.
If -- if he needs help, even after he gets parole, if he gets a sentence but technically or by application, the trial appointed -- court appointed attorney's duties are --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yeah -- but.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Oh!

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- practice down there.
Well now, I suppose after the sentence, it would've been too late then to withdraw the plea of guilty or would it not?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: I -- I believe it would, yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That has to -- a motion to withdraw of plea of guilty has to be made before sentence is --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: If any -- before submission to the jury.

Now, in -- I'd like to address my further argument to the second point and that is the question of applying the provision of the Eighth Amendment prescription, approval and unusual against the death -- against the offense of a common law robbery.

Now, this is a direct attack upon Title 14, Section 415 of the Code of Alabama which is the penalty statute for the common offense of robbery and we all know that the common law offense of robbery is the its essential's elements are the taking of property with -- from a person with the violence or with a threat of violence.
Now, the attack on this statute is because the breadth and range of it, a simple assault with a larceny can give you the death penalty under this statute.
Now, in application of this provision of the Eighth Amendment, this Court has indicated certain standards or certain things that they look at.
One of them is that it's not a static concept.

That's its not a non-progressive thing that it moves with the times and that they've in -- even indicated -- you have even indicated in an -- a more enlightened society, it might encompass greater and greater things and I am saying to this Court today that Alabama is the only State that has this common law offense of robbery with the death penalty.

And I submit that in the light of this Court's decisions, decisions such as Weems 60 years ago when this Court knocked down a punishment where a feller -- he falsified some Government documents and he got 12 years imprisonment and loss of his civil rights.
This Court at that time 1910 said that that one of the standards is the disproportionate, disproportionality of the offense with the punished.

Now, looking directly at Alabama, Alabama -- the crime of unpremeditated murder with malice in Alabama, the maximum punishment is life imprisonment yet for larceny, and a simple assault, you can get the death penalty.
I respectfully submit that that this standard of disproportionality is applicable to Edward Boykin.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean robbery, don't you?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Robbery, common law robbery as it is.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's the difference between common law robbery -- what is it that the other states have that Alabama doesn't have?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well, the other states have a statutory form of robbery classifying it in aggravation such as armed robbery.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Which adds what to attacking a man, threatening with a weapon, threatening to kill him and so forth, and talking his money, what does it add to that, the other states?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well, it adds the description of aggravation.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The aggra -- I mean, what conduct, what does he have to do in addition to that?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well, in a statutorily -- in an armed robbery statute he has to be armed or he has to kill somebody or whatever classification or qualification these statutes give it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well all this common -- all statutory robberies as I understand it based on the fact that one meets another or find him, threatened him with a weapon, if he doesn't give him his property and takes it away from him or tries to, isn't that statutory robbery as well as common law robbery?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: No, sir.
In common law robbery you can have conceivably a school boy in a corridor, in a high school in Alabama can snatch a book away from another student and under the statute in Alabama he can get death.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's conceivable.
Did you ever hear of a thing like this?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: No, sir.
I never have nor have I ever heard of really in terms of thinking that a feller who didn't kill anybody wouldn't get death, wouldn't sacrifice his own life for it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean, you've never heard of anybody being convicted robbery without killing somebody?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: No, sir.
I'm saying that it is shocking to think even under the Judeo-Christian concepts that we work on that a life must be taken when no life was --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But that --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: -- was taken.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I don't know what's the custom now, but it certainly it was --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- 50 years ago, it was said that --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Well Your Honor, I am not up here saying that robbery is not a serious crime.
It is most serious but we got to recognize that life is a fundamental thing, life is a fundamental right too.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Each life.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Each life.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The victim and the person who does it.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.
They --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They threatened victim, his life's pretty dear too, isn't it.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Most dear.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Gibbons, the printed appendix doesn't contain any transcript at all of how this jury was qualified the voir dire of the jury, is that available anywhere?
Is there a typewritten transcript to that in the original record?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It is not available and assuming that the practice is as it -- as I know it to be it was not transcribed.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Can you -- I have in mind this -- perhaps you might guess the decision of this Court in the Witherspoon case --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Witherspoon.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- Witherspoon against Illinois, you make no contention under that decision but it occurred to me that there might well be one to make.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: That -- that maybe so but the record here doesn't disclose, I mean I know or I can -- it's conjecture, I don't want to go outside the record --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, what's the --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: -- but the practice is, to qualify them as -- have they been doing for a long time.
And that is if you've got -- I think -- I think if it appeared in the record, you would have a contravention with the Witherspoon case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Does the -- do the statutes or laws or case law of Alabama with respect to qualifying a jury in a capital case throw any light on this question?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What did they --?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: There --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Scoops -- what's -- what's the purport of them?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Oh, the -- they hold that it's a challenge for cause if a perspective juror has any hesitancy in giving the death penalty.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It occurs to me that you representing a client under sentence of death have put a good many eggs in one basket and if you have a Witherspoon claim, who do you make it or perhaps federal habeas corpus is a more appropriate place for that and perhaps you've considered that.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Gibbons, as I understand it, you are here attacking the constitutionality of the Alabama statute on its face that is to say you're saying that the statute is bad apart from its -- the facts of this particular case would cause a statute authorizes the jury to fix death sentence in the case of Robert and you point out that Alabama used the common law definition of robbery.
Under -- I don't remember saying in your brief, a reference to just how Alabama views the definition of the common law crime of robbery.
From your argument I take it that any sort of unlawful taking, they need force --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: A taking with violence or with the threat of violence.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Alright, now are there states in which the crime of armed robbery is punishable by death.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And what happened here was in fact an armed robbery, there is no dispute about that is there that is to say that Boykin was carrying a gun.
Boykin did in fact use the gun in the robbery.
Boykin did in fact discharge the gun and in fact a girl in the store was wounded in the calf of her leg, am I correct?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That is correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, that would be armed robbery within the definition of other states, right?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Your point however is that it's not necessary -- is your point, that its not necessary for us to reach the constitutionality of the armed robbery death penalty statutes because you are asking us to consider this statute on its phase without reference to the facts of this particular case, is that right?

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: That's correct sir.

A -- aside from what this Court may think of murder, say, as justifying the death penalty, the question before the Court as I see it and the issue I'm trying to make is that the death penalty for robbery is cruel and unusual, is disproportionate, it -- it comes in a time when no other state except Alabama applies and it --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But here your problem however is that here you have an armed robbery and you have an armed robbery in the course of which somebody -- the -- Boykin did shoot and somebody was wounded but its not a -- just a simple unaggravated robbery.
Your attack must be and well I suppose you wouldn't be averse to attacking that as a basis for the death penalty but the other prong of your attack I take is that the statute is bad or over breadth.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Is bad on its face because of the expanse and range to which it can be applied.
Mr. Chief Justice, may I reserve whatever time I have left for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You may, you may Mr. --

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Clark.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
In April and May of 1966, Mobile, Alabama experienced a series of robbery.
One Edward Boykin was arrested.
The grand jury returned five indictments against him for robbery.
I would like to point out the time element and the space of the city involved.
These five robberies took place from April the 23rd 1966.
That was the first one.
There was one on May the 3rd, one on May the 5th, one on May the 8th, one on May the 8th.

The manner of operation was that this young man went into either grocery store or drugstore service station and would exhibit a pistol and commit robbery and then when he would leave, he fired the pistol so nobody would follow him out.
There was one wounding of a little girl.
I believe, the evidence shows that he fired into the floor, the bullet ricocheted and hit this young lady in the leg.
Now, at the time of the trial the court appointed, one Evan Austill, is the court appointed attorney to represent --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What was his name?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Evan Austill, A-U-S-T-I double L judge.
His father and he had practiced together.
The father has been a member of the bar for many years.
After --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I gather that you don't raise the question of the -- these questions being properly presented or do you?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You don't mention it on your brief?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I'm not the going to but I would stand on my brief, I think it explains some of it Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you raise -- do you speak of -- about that in your brief?
No.
It was just the jurisdictional question, it was not just a --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Which particular question was that Your Honor?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Whether we can reach questions which were not raised and decided under your State Supreme Court?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, I feel that under this Section, Title 15, Section 382, 1-13 wherein the Supreme Court considered all the things raised at the trial that you could do that sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: As far as it appears from what I've been able to a glean, of course we don't have the briefs of the parties before the Supreme Court before us but really nothing at all was raised at the trial.
There was simply a guilty plea and then as counsel has said, five sentences of death on one -- on this petitioner and that's all that appears plus some evidence of his -- of the conduct.

And then in the Supreme Court of Alabama all that appears that they considered of the questions raised here was whether or not the trial court failed to protect the petitioner's right to due process for -- with regard to his plea of guilty as you put it.
And that's the only thing they considered.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And neither one of the other two questions so far as I can find out was raised or considered or decided in any of the courts of Alabama.
Is -- am I wrong about that?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
You are correct that it could have been considered although they did not mentioned under that Title 15, Section 382 wherein --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It wasn't raised at the trial?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Either one of these two odd questions.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
Not raised at the trial.
A while ago you raised the question about the Witherspoon matter --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Whether Witherspoon applies to this.

I would like to call Your Honor's attention to appendix page 10 and 11 wherein Mr. Signey Flagger of the Assistant District Attorney prosecuting the case pointed out they had 12 jurors sitting in a box, would they be alright in the defendant there said they would and his attorney, Mr. Austill said the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, Mr. Clark is there anything in the record to show that any one of those jurors have asked any question at all about anything at any time?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
This is the entire matter and I have the original record here and nothing was said by qualifying them as to death penalty.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: It was an agreed jury.
Both sides agreed that they would be --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We are even not very qualified, don't we?
We don't even know where the other 21 though?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: They want a jury.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We don't even know what they can hear?
Nobody questioned him at all, are you -- what is the practice, you just pick 12 people and put them in a jury box?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
You pick 12 and then you qualify them and then --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But where is the qualification in this record.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: By agreement, both sides agreed that they --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Now the record says it -- well, the judge says, If I'm correct, there are 12 people there.
That's what he says on page 10, If I'm correct that there are 12 on the panel of jurors seated in the jury box.
And he says, Is that satisfy -- satisfactory?
Both sides said, Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That Mr. Flagger was one of the sides and that he is a District Attorney there prosecuting --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Him.
And then isn't it also true that at the end the judge said, Are you the same jury, was here yesterday?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He said --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- jurors are selected for a week, the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: The juries in Alabama are selected for that week of --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The same 12?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, he said, Young man I had to call you back as applied and misses something that acknowledge not where they just -- near the end there, well, he says, You were here.
I'll get the page in just a moment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How is this jury selected?
The ordinary method is --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
They argue --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- at the beginning of the week, the sheriff brings in jurors names --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They're selected --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: From the jury roll.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And the judge then qualifies them as to whether or not they're able to serve the jurors on account of their age.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That -- that is correct.
There was -- already been selected.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And then during the week, they divide it up and the man hasn't decided a question which says special qualification in regard to a particular case, they ask questions?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is correct.
Did this -- the jury had been --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Or that he was qualified at the beginning of the week, I assume.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, this one had been qualified as to that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, on page 32, some of you gentlemen were on the jury yesterday.
What's the meaning of that, it varies from day to day?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Punishment?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Does it vary or -- I thought you said the same 12 seat throughout the week?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
I said that the panel that -- they call at least 50 jurors.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, just one more question.
Is -- is there anything in this record that shows that the court explained to the jury the range of sentence?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
They all charged there was not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, the jury did not have any idea at all?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I -- I beg your pardon, may I quote from the actual record, record page 30.
He said, If that board, he gave a definition of robbery.
Now, robbery once again gentlemen is a felonious taking of money or goods of value from another against his will and without his permission by violence of putting him in fear.
That boils it down in a nutshell just what robbery is.
Now, it carries from 10 years minimum in the penitentiary to the supreme penalty of death by electrocution.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What page is that on?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is on -- that's the old rule charge --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It's page 32.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: The page is -- is it on page 32 -- page 32 in the appendix.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I -- what is there that you just read that shows why you should give death in one case and ten years in another, that's my point?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there anything other than that?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, there was no direction as to how you would do that.
However, this Court pointed out in I believe it was Giaccio versus Pennsylvania, I think it was one of them, that they could do that.
A jury could find the degree.
There was nothing prohibiting that.
Now, I would point out that in Alabama, robbery is a capital offense.
That of course means it carries a death penalty and the -- they can, to a lesser degree give anywhere from death on down to 10 years.
And that's left to the jurors discretion now in spite of no instructions, you do have this, that this jury has heard the entire trial.
They have been able to determine how severe or a case of robbery this is in this particular instance that there was a gun used, there was violence and they confessed on that.
They are the best ones to judge how severe the sentence should be.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The -- the entire trial is between pages 10 and page 31 --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- of the record.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- that is the entire evidence they put on.
In Alabama when you have a plea of guilty such as we had here, they put on a prima facie case.
Now in all five of these cases, I think they called seven witnesses.
That's also required.
You have the man pleading guilty which is judicial confession to that effect.
He had a plea of guilty.
You have that plus the prima facie case made out by the state.
We maintain that sufficient to put it to the jury.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Clark I know that on the transcript on 33, as the judge says, it's not in the hands of -- it is now in the hands of the state this have pronounced the sentence.
And it is up to the Governor if he cares to do anything about it.
It's not up to the trial judge.
Now, could we -- could you tell us whether he has -- whether there has been appeal to the Governor in this case?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
There has not been one yet because of this petitioner for this honorable court.
Had there not been one to this Court, then about two or three days before his execution there would -- been a hearing in the governor's office, a clemency hearing.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is that automatic or?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That is automatic.
At this hearing he may appear by himself, by attorney, his family, his minister.
I have been at some of them that they've had as many as 35 or 40 people to speak for this man and ask that his case be commuted to life imprisonment.
But as you pointed out that there has been on a district --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: When was the last execution in Alabama?
They didn't have one last year, did you have?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I remember --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That's has been several years.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- in the entire nation.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: In my brief I've pointed out one that was in 1964 that I handled that case through the Alabama Supreme Court and it went on to electrocution.
That incidentally was one for robbery.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It also involved a very horrible killing too, didn't it?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
But may I explain that, Your Honor.
In Alabama --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you did in your brief or --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Certainly, you can explain it freely.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, I -- I would have politely.
But in that particular case, there was a robbery and also that the man committed a murder while -- during this robbery.

It just happen that he was going with this young lady, he was a married man with a family and as the district attorney determined in that case that there were -- had two indictment, one for murder and one for robbery that it would be better to prosecute under robbery.
In Alabama they regard robbery as a serious offense.
Now a good attorney could have possibly --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You don't suppose the --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- attacked the young lady's reputation and maybe they'd been merely held manslaughter conviction.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But all of the -- I gather that the -- all of the circumstances of the robbery including this very gruesome --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: All they did was --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- it was a bizarre sort of killing where it was brought before the jury, is that correct?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What he took was the young woman's car after killing.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Car, jewelry and some money.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: May I ask Mr. Clark, is your automatic appeal statute, would it apply had Boykin got a prison sentence instead of the death sentence?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
That applies merely to the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Only whether --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- death sentence.
Yes, sir.
He could've asked for an appeal and in granting one, also an attorney, a transcript of the record.
Now --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And I gather that special statute is searching in the record, does that apply only with the automatic appeal statute applies?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
The appellate courts had that duty in our case --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In all cases?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That's --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: All criminal pleadings.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- look into the record.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Now the -- pardon.
There was something brought out about a motion for a new trial, usually that's done by the attorney who is appointed to handle the defense of that trial.
Also in a case which results in the death penalty, the same attorney goes right onto the Supreme Court.
In one form, it takes back, however, Mr. Gibbons is representing the defendant on appeal to the Supreme Court of Alabama and on a certiorari to this Court.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: May I ask you further sir, let's suppose that a defendant were tried on one count of robbery then the jury has a problem of fixing the punishment, is there any -- I don't suppose there's anything like a pre-sentence report or any evidence introduced as to his history, is there?
What is your practice?
Is there any effort to duplicate in front of the jury what is in the --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- in the ordinary pre-sentence report by the man's family background and what kind of person he's been and whether this is an isolated incident or part of a long history of crime, the sort that a judge usually ask before him?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
Not in this type of case because jury returns a verdict.
However, the defendant could put on character witnesses, things of that nature during the trial.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: During the trial?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
He could do that.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But suppose he had a led an exemplary life and suppose his counsel decided that for strategic reasons that he didn't want to get the question of guilt whether you did this or not makes up with the facts about the man's life which is of course kind of thing, conceivable, I'd badly described it but --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- sure, you'll agree that it is conceivable that a lawyer might make a strategic judgment of that sort.
Then the jury would have to consider punishment without anything before it as to what kind of man this is.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is true.
That would be a matter of trial strategy and --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- and I don't think the --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- she might be a very, very critical one in which the lawyer makes the judgment in good faith and with professional competence that he later desperately regrets.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And his client therefore -- client is electrocuted, he probably regrets that even more.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I feel that that this case here represents one of those.
This attorney entered a plea of guilty for the man and I suppose assuming that there would a prison sentence.
What brought this on as I pointed out earlier is there had been a series of robberies and the jury returned this verdict.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, this trial took place September of 1966.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is correct, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that's when the jury was in -- the panel sworn as indicated on page 10 of the appendix.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Long before this Court's decision in the Witherspoon case, so that the defense counsel was not aware of any right to challenge the jury on the basis -- the constitutional basis on which Witherspoon was decided, was corrected?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is true.

However, he did have those challenges that were set out in Title 30, Section 55 and 57 and in the argument last week, I pointed out that if he had fixed opinion against capital punishment, could be the one on the Section 57.
However --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How can you --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: We contend that they waived that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: It was by agree --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It wasn't a known waiver though was it?
It couldn't have been any known waiver of any right under the Witherspoon case because the Witherspoon case hadn't been decided.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: And that is another thing I would like to point out to this Court.
This man still has his opportunity to go back before the state court on coram nobis and bring these things up.
At that time he would be appointed an attorney.
They would have a full hearing on these matters, the identical matters brought up now.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is it still the law in Alabama that good character alone could be charged to the jury sufficient to generate a reasonable doubt of guilt?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That -- that's still the law.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, here there was a plea of guilt though so that would --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That would be --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- hardly --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is a court not inquired into the voluntariness of a plea in Alabama?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
They should.
The record does not reflect that here.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, wouldn't you think that it should be done by all means in a capital case where a man's life is at stake?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why wasn't it done here?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I don't know that it wasn't done Your Honor.
It's just not recorded as such.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, can you tell us whether it was or was not done?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
I was not present at the trial.

However, I'd like to point out to Your Honor, you have Rule 11, your federal rules of criminal procedure that require such warning to the defendant and while no particular writs shouldn't be observed by the trial court such as a form finding a recitation of plea was entered with understanding and affirmed the duty, nonetheless exists on the part of the trial court to advise the accused fully.
And that's recited from Hulsey versus United States, that's 369 F.2d 284.
So apparently in your federal court volume, on your federal rules you have the duty.
You don't have to find, it simply show that in the record.
And there is no showing that this man was not advised to the serious and sentence relief.
Besides that he had an attorney to represent him.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Who tried the case?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: This one -- the particular one was before Judge Gillard.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How long has he been a judge?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Judge Gillard has been on the bench I think about 6 or 8 years as a circuit judge.
At one time he serves as a probe judge also.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What are his initials?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Walter Gillard, I believe.
And I don't the middle initial.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was he in the span of Palmer Gillard?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Palmer, his brother I believe and his father was I believe Palmer Gilliard also.
He was our senior member of the bar.
He died at the age of 103.
Now --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The judge -- I'm looking at page 33 of the printed appendix, in sentencing the petitioner indicated at least by negative implication of you will that he had some discretion not to follow the jury's recommendation of a death sentence.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is it --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- they as a --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He says in case number 15520, the court will impose a sentence according to the verdict of the jury.
And in case number 15521, the court again will follow the verdict of the jury.
So on and so -- which leads to a possible implication that he didn't have a duty to do so.
Am I -- what is the law of Alabama on that?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Notwithstanding the verdict, I believe is that the judge could send it back?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Send it back to whom?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: For what?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: The jury didn't agree did a predetermined sentence.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I wonder what kind of instructions.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: He could instruct the jury just on that matter.
He thought it was -- did not warrant that penalty.
However in Alabama your death penalty is provided of robbery and --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: He'd already instructed them that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If they could --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: They have thought --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- that they did have that option.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, is there any authority from that?
I don't -- as I read this perhaps I'm wrong, perhaps it's a little different from the way my Brother Stewart reads it.
I read it all this judge thought he could is to make a recommendation for clemency which will be to the Governor.

When you read the first couple of sentences of what he said there but can I know judge's -- trial judges can do things that aren't always strictly according to the book I suppose but is there any authority in the law for him to send the case back to the jury and ask him to tell, instruct them to reconsider their verdict.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I don't have it before me Your Honor but there have been cases where they have done that.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: They have done it --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- but you don't know of any --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
I don't have --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- statutory or case law --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- that approves it.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Now there was something brought out in the brief about the finding of guilty by the jury and the fixing of the sentence by that same jury violated his constitutional rights.

I believe this honorable court in a footnote in Giaccio versus Pennsylvania held that in so holding we intend to cast no doubt whatever on the constitutionality of the settled practice in many states to lead the juries fixing defendant's guilty crime, the power to fix punishment within legally prescribed limits.
Now, I found two cases when courts had followed that one is in California, In re Anderson, California Supreme Court on November 18th of 1968 filed it.

That was in a murder case however -- but they had -- they under I believe Section 160 of their Criminal Code, the jury could find the person guilty of murder in the first degree and under the Section 160.1 the same jury could fix his punishment at either death or life imprisonment.

And Supreme Court of California held that that was no violation of his constitutional rights and this same thing was followed in the Supreme Court of Washington, Washington versus Smith in the Washington Supreme Court on October 29th, 1968.
And the last paragraph of that opinion I think is a burden here.
The defendant's argument against the death sentence on moral and practical grounds are persuasive however they should be addressed to the legislature.
If as they maintain a majority of people today are impose to the death penalty an effort to get the legislature to eliminate it should have a considerable chance of success.
That's our contention if there's objection to the death penalty.
The proper way is to take that through the legislature and this --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: May I -- I'm sorry to ask you so many questions.
May I ask you a question about the nature of the trial here, now robbery is a capital offense?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And the court does not -- does the court accept the guilty without more or is this a trial on the question of guilt?
Was the jury informed that the defendant had pleaded guilty?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
They were informed and the jury --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That doesn't appear here, does it?
But they are informed that the defendant had pleaded guilty?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
It doesn't appear from the record here but when there has been a plea of guilty in Alabama the jury hears a prima facie case to determine the seriousness of the crime.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: To deter -- in other words --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: To determine the sentence.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So do you argue that in the sense, this is not a unitary trial, what happened here in the sense that this trial was on the question of punishment?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
It was meant -- principally the question of punishment.
There had been a plea of guilty already.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And that that plea of guilty is accepted in --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- in Alabama even if -- suppose this had been a murder case, is it a custom on Alabama to accept a plea of guilty?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Usually when they enter a plea of guilty to murder they'll enter a plea of murder to the second degree which would cover the life sentence.
But --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But it's clear -- you don't know of any situation --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
They --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- a plea of --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- to track them --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- guilt.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- first degree murder.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: They -- they go to trial?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: They go to trial.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And they don't accept the plea of guilty.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But despite the fact that the ultimate result may be the same here namely electrocution.
In a robbery case, the court will accept and lay before the jury the plea of guilty.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is that correct?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Are you saying it is a matter of law, the court is not allowed to accept a plea of guilty to first degree murder of Alabama or are you just telling that that's the practice?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I know of no case in which that has happened Your Honor that they held --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, for example in the state that -- with which I'm most familiar as a matter of law, a trial court is limited in accepting, that being allowed to accept a plea of guilty to first degree.
Is there any such law in your state?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
I know of none but I had in practice --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You just mean as a matter of practice they cup a plea to second degree murder?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, if they plead guilty to murder in the first degree unless it's changed that time, was it?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is the law -- the judge is required to call a jury, give the jury enough evidence to show a prima facie case just that number of witnesses and to show -- give the jury enough information on which it supposedly he could -- they could rest a verdict.
And that's the way it's done and by the first -- it was done in that way in the first place.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has that been changed?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
I believe Mr. Justice Black, that's the answer to my question.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So it's not just a penalty to trial as perhaps you stated and I didn't get the implications of it.
This is something more than just a penalty trial, its penalty trial plus a trial in which a prima facie case is made that the guilty plea is warranted?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, you could not have the conviction without putting on a prima facie case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But could the jury after the prima facie case goes in and the judge says lets go the jury, is the jury permitted to find him innocent?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
It would not be on this robbery.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And didn't the jury's verdict actually recite that the jury found him guilty as charged, the indictment on his plea of guilty.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What the verdict actually recites.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I think that's what this is.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What happened if the judge finds a prima facie case not made out?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: He could so instruct the jury.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Instruct the jury of what?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That no prima facie case was made out.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Therefore --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Then I'll assume the defense counsel would then move for a directive verdict.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: After a plea of guilty?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: After a plea of guilty?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That would taint the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What I mean is, would that be -- is that ever happened?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
Not to my knowledge.
Prima facie case wouldn't take too much to put on Your Honor just one or two witnesses at the most.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I have a very vivid recollection of that practice, I thought I was appointed and the -- it was -- a jury was called, a jury was selected, I had a trade whereby he was not to get this, the jury came back and tried to defy the court's order.
They wanted to give him a death sentence on a prima facie case and the judge find -- they told them they could give it to him but he set it aside.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's all they accepted.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That's what I mentioned a while ago, would it satisfy --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That is the practice -- that was the practice then to my knowledge.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Clark, I noticed that on page 25 of the petitioner's brief that he raises a question, a guilty plea to be effective must be made voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently.
And he says a trial judge has an affirmative constitutional duty to ascertain whether or not a guilty plea was voluntarily made.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, if we take this record as it is in this transcript, there is nothing to indicate that there was anything done by the Court to determine whether it was voluntarily made.
Must we assume that this is all that the Court went on?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes of course they're substantially the same as the original record.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So if we --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: However -- oh, you -- I get what you mean sir.
No, sir.
You are assuming that he did not because it does not appear in the record, is that correct?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Are we entitled this --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: And I believe the case cite --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- that we must decide it on this record, that that's all there is on that subject matter.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

Now the case of O'Connor versus Cochran that he cited in support of that had to do with the confession I believe but -- I did cite a case wherein it -- there was no particular format that they had to use or nothing -- in the effect on --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If it isn't a question of format, there was absolutely nothing here, that's the problem, absolutely nothing.

Now, is there anything in the record that we can consider to negate this statement that a trial judge has an affirmative constitutional duty to ascertain whether or not a guilty plea was voluntarily made?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
But all it appears there is not shown in the record, exactly the questions he asked.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: If he --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, if we decide this issue, this particular issue, are we entitled to decide it fairly on what is in this transcript and nothing more?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That's -- that's all the spoken and written words that were transcribed and put in the record either in the record that it was before the Alabama Supreme Court of this Honorable Court.

However, as I've pointed and I cited one case that there's nothing that requires to my knowledge that it appear in the record that he did so advised and in fact say, Mr. Boykin, you know that you can get the death penalty.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I wasn't asking about your law, I was asking about the facts in this case.
This is all we have to go.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That's correct.
Your Honor I believe that that in my brief explained my points and I thank you for your --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Gibbons.

turn.speaker: e_graham_gibbons
turn.label: Mr. E. Graham Gibbons
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
I have just a couple of comments in rebuttal.
